facts.disputed_property: S. Nos. 137 and 140 of Deh Phulji Taluka Johi
facts.respondent_claim: Purchased by respondent's father Soomar through registered sale-deed in 1917 and remained in possession.
facts.appellant_claim: Entries in Record-of-Rights were made in 1927 in appellant's father's name and authenticated in 1959.

initial_appeal.result: Entries in Record-of-Rights canceled and case remanded to Mukhtiarkar Johi (Order dated 1970-09-22).

subsequent_appeal.result: Appeal rejected, Deputy Commissioner's order upheld (Order dated 1971-03-03).

further_action.result: Directed respondent to seek remedy in Civil Court (Order dated 1972-02-14).

issues: Whether the application addressed to the Minister could be treated as a Revenue appeal.
Whether the application was time-barred and lacked proper form.
Whether the entries in the Record-of-Rights made in 1927 were fraudulent.
Whether the matter involved complex questions of law and fact requiring adjudication by Civil Court.

appellant: Application was not addressed to the Deputy Commissioner and was time-barred.
Entries in Record-of-Rights were made in 1927 and authenticated in 1959.
Respondent and his father did not claim the land for over 43 years.
Deputy Commissioner lacked jurisdiction to decide the matter at a belated stage.
respondent: Land was purchased by respondent's father through registered sale-deed in 1917.
Possession remained with respondent's family as evidenced by revenue records.
Entries in Record-of-Rights were fraudulent and should have been corrected.
Revenue authorities were obligated to update records based on registered sale-deed.

decision.summary: The appeal is allowed, and the order of the Deputy Commissioner, Dadu, is set aside.
decision.reasoning: The matter involves complex questions of law and fact regarding property title, which should be decided by a competent Civil Court.

legal_references: West Pakistan Land Revenue Act, Section 42(6)(8)
Old Sind Land Revenue Code, Section 135-J
